Question.Text: A 72-year-old man presents to a clinic in Laos with extensive, painful verrucous skin lesions on his left foot and lower leg. Ten years prior, he had a leech bite on the dorsum of his left foot. Three days before admission his ankle became painful and swollen.

Answer: Chromoblastomycosis - The elderly patient presents with extensive chronic verrucous (warty) skin lesions on the lower extremity following a leech bite 10 years ago in Laos. The images show cauliflower-like verrucous plaques and characteristic copper-colored sclerotic cells (medlar bodies) on microscopy, typical of this chronic subcutaneous fungal infection caused by dematiaceous fungi from traumatic inoculation.
